TopicTitle: Please explain these settings to me

Articles.Content:
Hello all,

could anybody please explain some settings options to me? They are all from the settings - graphics window, and I have no idea what they mean or what they do.

-fallback part shaders

-anti aliasing

-v sync

-pixel light count

-shadow cascades

On some I understand the wording (bit of a language barrier here) but dont understand what it exactly does. Some insight would be appreciated.

Many thanks in advance

Daf

No language barrier here, but most of those don't explain anything, rather just restate the setting in a sentence with no further info:

"Pixel Light Count

  • Controls how many Pixel Lights can be in the scene at any time. See Unity documentation for more details."

-fallback part shaders

Ugly shader model 2 shaders, they make the grass really dark and can make windows opaque, don't use them.

 

-anti aliasing

Makes the edges less pixellated and jaggy, smoothing the image.

 

-v sync

Forces the screen to only update between passes, not during a draw, helps eliminate tearing.

 

-pixel light count

How many lights you can have at the same time, too low and some won't cast light, too high can cause slowdown.

 

-shadow cascades

The number of passes the shadow renderer makes, higher gives smoother shadows, but costs performance.

59 minutes ago, Dafni said:

-fallback part shaders

A shader is a program that draws something on the screen - the code that gets executed on the video card that, pixel by pixel, 'paints' the screen with the bits from that part's textures, lighting, etc. Some shaders are very complicated (reflections, multiple lighting sources, physically based rendering); others are not. More to the point, some are written and tested on every video card on the planet (e.g. Unity's built-in shaders), while others are built by small studios or even hobbyists without access to heavy testing rigs, and may not work on all video cards. This setting tells the renderers that, if there are any issues with the shader they prefer (the fancy-shmancy one), then fall back to the simpler, plainer looking one.

1 hour ago, Dafni said:

-anti aliasing

When you render a 3-D thing to a screen with pixels, each pixel is rendered as either on one part of the object or another, when really some pixels should be partially on one part and partially on the other. Sometimes, this can produce odd, distracting visual artifacts. Anti-aliasing renders at a higher resolution and then scales it down to get rid of the blocky effect, but it can be very slow, and lower end graphics cards have trouble with it.

1 hour ago, Dafni said:

-v sync

The game engine, by default, renders to the screen as fast as it can; when one frame is done it moves immediately to the next. This is normally not a problem, but if it's halfway through rendering such a frame and your monitor decides now is the time to show the frame, it'll show part one frame and part of the screen on the next frame, creating a tearing effect. V Sync means that, if the framerate is above a certain FPS (the refresh rate of your monitor), it will keep it steady at that rate instead, preventing the tearing effect.

1 hour ago, Dafni said:

-pixel light count

There are two kinds of lights in the Unity engine: Vertex lights (very basic, very old-fashioned lighting, where only the vertex is calculated), and pixel lights (where every pixel seen is calculated). Anytime you see a spotlight in any game, that's a pixel light; vertex lights simply can't do that effect, though they usually work fine for things like sunlight. Pixel lights are taxing on the video card, especially if there are a lot of them.

1 hour ago, Dafni said:

-shadow cascades

In order to render realtime shadows, the scene is rendered as a depth map from the point of view of the light source. Like anytime a scene is rendered, this is made up of pixels. If the scene has big objects, then the shadows are rendered with big pixels. But the area right up near the screen might need some extra detail, and that's what shadow cascades do: They render smaller portions of the 'shadow depth map' at higher resolution.

Thank you for all the information!
